Multi-network DIDs are also supported, if the proper configuration is provided during setup.

gets resolved on the rinkeby testnet, and represents a
distinct identifier than the generic one.
The did resolver takes the ethereum address, checks for the current owner, looks at contract events and builds a simple DID document.
The minimal DID document for a an ethereum address
with no transactions to the registry looks like this:
The DID document is built by using read only functions and contract events on the
Any value from the registry that returns an ethereum address will be added to the
array of the DID document with type
Each identity always has an owner address. By default it's the same as the identity address, but check the read only contract function
on the deployed version of the EthrDIDRegistry contract.
The Identity owner will always have a
with the id set as the DID with the fragment
An entry is also added to the
array of the DID document with type

The latest event can be efficiently looked up by checking for one of the 3 above events at that exact block.

Non ethereum keys, service elements etc can be added using attributes. Attributes only exist on the blockchain as contract events of type
and can thus not be queried from within solidity code.

This is used to perform a Diffie-Hellman key exchange and derive a secret key for encrypting messages to the DID that lists such a key.

only refers to the key encoding in the resolved DID document.
Attribute values should always be hex encoded.
